skill.name: enact/docs/guide
skill.description: LLM guide for creating, publishing, and running Enact tools. Enact provides containerized tools with structured I/O for AI agents.
skill.summary: Guide for creating and managing Enact containerized tools
skill.author: EnactProtocol

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing Enact tool creation guide. All static findings are false positives: sigstore bundle contains legitimate cryptographic signatures, backticks are markdown code formatting, API_KEY is a placeholder example. No executable code or malicious patterns present.

content.value_statement: Developers need guidance on building containerized tools with structured I/O. This skill provides a comprehensive guide for creating, publishing, and running Enact tools with Docker containers.
actual_capabilities: Provides complete reference for Enact tool configuration including YAML frontmatter, inputSchema, outputSchema, and environment variables
Shows examples for Python, Node.js, Rust, Go, and Shell tool implementations
Documents the publish and sign workflow for sharing tools
Explains secret management using OS keyring instead of .env files
limitations: This is a documentation skill only - it provides information, not executable actions
Does not install or run Enact CLI tools
Does not create or modify local tool files

use_cases.title: Learn Enact tool basics
use_cases.description: New users understand Enact concepts, tool structure, and configuration format.

use_cases.title: Create first tool
use_cases.description: Developers follow step-by-step examples to build their first containerized tool in their preferred language.

use_cases.title: Reference configuration options
use_cases.description: Experienced users look up field references for inputSchema, outputSchema, secrets, and publishing options.

prompt_templates.title: Get started with Enact
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create a new Enact tool? Explain the basic structure and required files.

prompt_templates.title: Configure environment variables
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to configure environment variables in Enact, especially how to handle secrets securely.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-language examples
prompt_templates.prompt: Give me examples of how to create Enact tools in Python, Node.js, Rust, and Go.

prompt_templates.title: Publish and share tools
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain the workflow for signing, publishing, and sharing Enact tools with others.

output_examples.input: How do I create an Enact tool?
output: An Enact tool needs two files in a directory:
1. enact.md - YAML frontmatter with tool metadata and documentation
2. main.py (or main.js, main.rs, etc.) - your tool code

output_examples.input: How do I handle secrets in Enact?
output: Use the secret field in your enact.md environment configuration:
Users set the secret via: enact env set API_KEY --secret --namespace myorg/tools
Secrets are stored in the OS keyring, never in .env files or code.

best_practices: Pin base images to specific versions (e.g., python:3.12-slim, not latest) for reproducibility
Define inputSchema and outputSchema to validate data flow between tools
Use the secret field for API keys and credentials to store them in OS keyring
anti_patterns: Using 'latest' tag for base images - causes unpredictable builds
Storing secrets in .env files or code - use the secret field instead
Skipping inputSchema validation - tools may receive unexpected data

faq.question: What is Enact?
faq.answer: Enact is a protocol for creating containerized tools with structured I/O. Tools run in Docker containers with validated inputs and outputs.

faq.question: What programming languages are supported?
faq.answer: Any language that can run in a Docker container. Examples include Python, Node.js, Rust, Go, and Shell scripts.

faq.question: How do I run a local tool?
faq.answer: Use 'enact run ./tool --input "key=value"' to test tools locally before publishing.

faq.question: How are secrets managed?
faq.answer: Define secrets in enact.md with secret: true. Users store them in OS keyring via 'enact env set' command.

faq.question: What is the difference between container and instruction tools?
faq.answer: Container tools have a command field and run in Docker. Instruction tools have no command and provide markdown interpreted by the AI.

faq.question: How do I publish a tool?
faq.answer: Run 'enact auth login', then 'enact sign ./tool', and finally 'enact publish ./tool' to publish to the registry.
